A band of elastic surrounds and gathers the base and the top portions thereof in pleats, and the sleeve is sufficiently elongated so that when the base is fitted over the mouth of the bag, the upper portion of the cover will fold over the club heads.
A cover for preventing water from entering a golf bag while removing clubs therefrom comprises a tubular sleeve formed of a water impervious, flexible material.
At the end of the period, the golfer was able to play and practice without LBP.
This invention protects the clubs and scorecard from inclement weather while allowing easy access to them and a positive attachment of the cover to the bag

2D sonographic diagnoses of disk dislocation in the closed mouth position and of joint degeneration showed significantly different results from the expected values (MRI) in chi(2) testing; 3D diagnoses of disk dislocation in closed mouth position, of joint degeneration, 2D and 3D diagnoses in open mouth position were nonsignificant.

A flexible golf bag cover for protecting the interior and contents of a golf bag of the type having an open top surrounded by a peripheral rim and having a carrying strap extending laterally from the rim.
A flexible, waterproof, lightweight compact cover for the top of a golf bag and for golf clubs having a first end and a second end.
The cover of this invention keeps clubs dry while in the bag, and, in addition, provides easy access and an unobstructed view thereof to facilitate selecting a club for play during such weather.
A golf bag cover for protecting golf clubs during inclement weather is disclosed.
To gain access to the golf club, the second end of the cover is lifted and the golfer may reach in to remove the golf club while still preventing rain from entering the top of the golf bag.
